comment_text: Better to have Commuter Constipation than Traveler's TROTS!

I wouldn't even describe it as constipation for me most of the time. I usually only poop once or twice a day anyway, and I never have trouble doing it when I need to, in fact, it's often easier than at home, I just don't seem to need to as often when I'm on vacation, and most of my vacations involve nothing more than a 150-200 mile drive northwest, nowhere near enough time or distance for jet lag to come into play. I rarely touch caffeine, I'm not the one driving, and I practically never drink alcohol. 8 guess maybe eating more snack foods might be part of it, but I'd guess something psychological, though after my high school psych class, I can never forget that everything psychological is in turn biological.

So there I was in Cochin, Kerala, India. Dropped a nice moderate size dookie at the B&B I was staying at after a quick nap before my trip back to Philadelphia. Went to the airport, flew for 4 hours, had a three hour layover at Doha, a 14 hour flight to NYC, transferred from JFK airport to Penn Station, Amtrak to Philadelphia and then a short schlep to my apartment...a total journey of near 30 hours; and I didn't have to poop! I still consider that a miracle and a story I will tell until my dying days!

Travellers constipation is AWESOME.

My Costa Rica trip years ago: I stayed hydrated and took a water bottle with me everywhere, I ate lots of fruit and vegetables, I hiked 30k through the jungle, and I only had a two hour time-zone difference...
but I still got severe traveler's constipation.

Guess that explains why I had such issues when going overseas for the first time two months ago. I was also taking antibiotics at the same time to fight SIBO when I traveled so I don't know if that contributed as well. The nice part about Japanese food is that it helps benefit the gut, especially with seafood, fermented side dishes, and veggie ingredients. Easily was able to eat close to a normal diet for once and it felt so nice not having flare ups the whole trip.

HYDRATION... If you are literally jumping from car to plane to car to sleep to car to work.  You need water.  If you don't properly hydrate your body will try to get water anywhere it can including your poop.  When dry fasting or just plain forgetting to drink water your body will hold onto your poop to sap as much moisture out of it that it can.  Just carry water with you and drink it as you go and you'll be fine.

I think this mainly happens due to the change in the toilet. The body is used to the one you regularly sit in and your internals are optimised to facilitate this. Change in the shape of the toilet will mess this optimised working. The greater the variation of the shape of the other toilet from your regular one, the greater your constipation.
